column1: Note: Colour coding for transcriptions: green text is N|uu, blue is Afrikaans, red is Khoekhoegowab (Nama) and black is English.

Film clip: 1997_01-01 
Katriena: Katriena Witbooi 
Petrus: Petrus Vaalbooi 
OS: Off screen
Keywords: Katriena Witbooi (Ouma),Petrus Vaalbooi, Nama language, ǂHanasen, kinship, biography, interview assistance, Willem Claasen, Elsie Vaalbooi, Petsi (place name).

column2: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): Grandmother do you know Mother? Describe </eng> <eng>her to him so that he … can understand well. He will not understand well.</eng>
column3:
<speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>Ken Ouma vir Ma? Verduidelik hom lat hy net ... mooi kan hoor. Hy sal nie mooi verstaan nie.</afr> <eng>
</eng>

column2: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: I know her from the time she had Jacoba …</eng>
column3: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <afr>Ek ken hom van die tyd wat hy Jacoba gehad het </afr> <afr>al …</afr>

column2:
<speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: I’ve known her since she was dating/married to 
Toper. While I was in […] they lived in Petsi, and when I 
started dating Willem Claasen from Petsi I relocated and 
moved there, that’s how I 
knew her, Elsie your mother. </eng>
column3:
<speaker>Katriena</speaker> <nam>Toperas ge ūhâ I ||aeba xu ta ǂan, ge ǂan. […] ta hâ tita hîas ge ||în ge Petsis ai hâ i sa, tsî Petsisa xu i ta ge Willem Klaaseba u tsîta ge tita ge ||naǀî doe, ||napa u ta ge ǂan. Elsisa, sa ma sa. </nam> <eng>
</eng>

column2:
<speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): Yes. </eng> <eng>Grandmother’s, Grandmother, Grandmother … was 
Grandmother … who, who is Grandmother? Grandmother’s </eng>
column3: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>Aha. Ouma se, Ouma, Ouma ... was Ouma …wie, wie’s Ouma? Ouma se naam?</afr>

column4: <notes>Khoekhoegowab, Niklaas transcribed and translated. Referring to male person. Female would be ‘Matis’</notes>

column2: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: Witbooi, the surname I was born with. My Father’s home-surname (diminutive) is Witbooi.</eng>
column3: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <afr>Witbooi, geboorte van. My Pa se huisievan is Witbooi.</afr>

column2:
<speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: My Mother, my 
Father is … Lena Witbooi and my Father is Hendrik Witbooi and I am Kartriena Witbooi.</eng>
column3:
<speaker>Katriena</speaker> <afr>My Ma en my Pa is … Lena Witbooi en my Pa is Hendrik Witbooi en ek is Katriena Witbooi. </afr> <eng>
</eng>

column4:
<notes>Pronounced Hansen but could be 
referring to the </notes>

column2: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): There it is! That’s how I want it.</eng>
column3: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>Daarsy! Dis soos ek hom wil hê.</afr>

column2: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): Now what must I say for Mother? Grandmother must really say something? How should I do it?</eng>
column3: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>Nou hoe moet ek vir Ma loop sê? Ouma moet darem iets sê? Hoe moet ek maak?</afr>

column2:
<speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): Yes look, Mother, Mother speaks the thing that Grandmother (speaks) well. Now help Mother. Now you 
(plural) must help Mother. </eng> <eng>Now, Grandmother how do you feel about standing 
alongside Mother? I still have to come back and recall the names and recall the people.</eng>
column3:
<speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>Ja kyk, Ma, Ma praat die ding wat Ouma-goed (praat). Nou vir Ma help. Nou moet julle vir Ma help. Nou hoe voel Ouma om vir Ma by te staan? Ek moet nog terugkom en die namekom vat, en die koppe kom vat.</afr> <eng>

</eng>
column4:
<notes>Petrus is asking 
Katriena for 
assistance in an 
upcoming interview. He is asking how 
she feels about 
serving in a 
supportive capacity during the interview by using their 
language (N|uu or Nama) with Mother. He wants their help to backtrack and 
recall more names and identify more 
people.</notes>

column2: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: I cannot say that I will stand alongside her </eng> <eng>because I don’t know how long </eng> <eng>…</eng>
column3: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <afr>Ek kan nie sê ek sal hom by staan nie want ek weet </afr> <afr>nie hoe lank …</afr>

column2: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): That’s it, that is truly the thing.</eng>
<speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: God will keep me alive. I don’t know.</eng>
<speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): No, now those are Mother’s fears.</eng>

<speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): And 
Grandmother can maybe still say that little bit.</eng>
column3: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>En Ouma kan nog miskien daai bietjie gee.</afr>

column2: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <eng>OS (Petrus): That little bit of language and to tell them how to do it – the people.</eng>
column3: <speaker>Petrus</speaker> <afr>Daai bietjie taal en vir hulle sê hoe moet hulle maak – die mense.</afr>

column2: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: Thus, let them who are alive take the land, those </eng>
<eng>who will live longer, children. Let me be strong to help the children.</eng>
column3: <nam>ûitsama se nî sâu-e nâ, |gôana. Īs |gaima tsî hui |gôana.</nam>

column2: <speaker>Katriena</speaker> <eng>Katriena: That is all that I want to say.</eng>
